title: Bay Area Open Science Group - Supporting an Open Source Software Journal: Strategies for Effective Editing and Engagement
description:
This month the Bay Area Open Science Group will be joined by Kelly L. Rowland. Kelly will discuss her experiences as editor for the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS), a journal dedicated to publishing articles about open source research software across domains. JOSS’ scope includes software that solves complex modeling problems in a scientific context, supports the functioning of research instruments or the execution of research experiments, or extracts knowledge from large data sets. Kelly is a Computer Systems Engineer in the User Engagement Group at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a division of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL). Before joining NERSC, she obtained her Ph.D. from UC Berkeley in Nuclear Engineering with a Designated Emphasis on Computational Science and Engineering. Kelly has been an editor for the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) since 2021.

The Bay Area Open Science Group is intended to bring together students, faculty, and staff from the Stanford, UCSF, and Berkeley community to learn about open science, discuss the application of open science practices in a research context, and meet other members of the community who are interested in (or already are) incorporating open science practices into their work. Learn more about the group and connect with us on our website.

Register for this event via Zoom

title: Data Science Help Desk
description:
Visit our virtual data science help desk! 

Introducing the virtual Data Science Help Desk, a place to ask your general questions about data science including how to download software or code packages, prep for upcoming data science classes, get started with programming, connect with data science expertise, and more. No appointments required, just drop in!

How does the Data Science Help Desk work?

At the Data Science Help Desk, we can answer general data science questions and connect you with a wealth of data science resources and expertise. The Help Desk is hosted by graduate student TAs of the Data Science Team twice a week on Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 2-3 pm subject to change to fit the needs of the UCSF community. Due to current COVID-19 guidelines, the Help Desk will be hosted on Zoom, but in-person Data Science Help Desk services at Mission Bay/Parnassus campuses may take place in the future. The Data Science Help Desk is open to the UCSF community including faculty, staff, and trainees.

We look forward to meeting you (virtually) at the Data Science Help Desk!

 

Access Help Desk: Zoom Link

title: 3D Printing Part 2: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing Part 1

Want to create your own models to 3D print in the Makers Lab?

Join Makers Lab staff for the second pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D design & modeling using the web-based application Tinkercad. This pop-up is for beginners, but all skills levels are welcome to attend.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Design a basic 3D model in Tinkercad
  2. Export a model out of Tinkercad for 3D printing
  3. Locate resources for continuing your learning with Tinkercad
  4. Identify other 3D design & modeling software for more advanced projects

Make sure to sign up for a Tinkercad account before the pop-up and use a three-button if you have one available. You don't even need to download Tinkercad, it is a free, web-based application that you can use anywhere, as long as you have an internet connection.

Need to design 3D models with more complex geometries? Attend an upcoming Fusion 360 pop-up! Unsure if Tinkercad is the right software for your project? Contact the Makers Lab for suggestions.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Machine Learning for Document Classification and Sentiment Analysis
description:
Note: Please register for this workshop with your UC email address. 

Overview

This workshop will review the process of preparing, cleaning, and formatting text for natural language processing projects. Topics will include stop words, n-grams, stemming, lemmatization, and other techniques for pre-processing text. Although we will populate and evaluate a machine learning text classification model, empahsis will be on the programming work involved in preparing text to build and populate the model rather than algorithms or analysis.

This workshop will take place online over UCSF Zoom. Registered participants will recieve an email through LibCal with connection information the day before the workshop.

Prerequisites

Familiarity with Python.

Instructor 

Geoffrey Boushey with the UCSF Library Data Science Initiative

Digital Humanities Sequence

This sequence is designed for people with no prior programming experience. The workshops start with core python and sql before moving into more advanced or specialized topics in digital humanities, with an emphasis on text analysis and machine learning. 

You are welcome to take any of these workshops without attending the entire series. No formal pre-reqs are enforced, but if you are new to Python or SQL, you’ll get the core programming skills necessary for the later workshops by attending Intro to Python Part 1 and Part 2 along with Intro to SQL. 

Registration Links: 

  • Intro to Python Part 1:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11946795
  • Intro to Python Part 2:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11946839
  • Intro to SQL:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11946900
  • Data Analysis with Python, Pandas, and SQL:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947263
  • Intro to Unix:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947161
  • Reading Data from APIs with Python, Pandas, and SQL:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947321
  • Machine Learning with Python and Scikit-Learn:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947452
  • Python Background for Text Analysis and Natural Language Processing:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947471
  • Machine Learning for Document Classification and Sentiment Analysis:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947489
  • Google Cloud Tools, BiqQuery, and VertexAI:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/11947492

title: Document Analysis using Google Cloud
description:
This workshop will be offered on-line over Zoom. All registered participants will recieve a Zoom link after registrations close, typically 24 hours prior to the start of the workshop. 

NOTE: Please register for this workshop using your UC or other university email address, if you have one.  

Google Cloud and AutoML offer a wide variety of tools for data analysis, including python workbooks, SQL, machine learning, document classification, OCR (text extraction), translation, sentiment analysis, and more. 

In this workshop, we'll review how to access and use these services using Google Colab, BigQuery, and AutoML.  

Prerequisites: To fully participate in the workshop exercises, you'll need SQL and Python knowledge at the level of the DSI intro workshop series. However, feel free to enroll if you'd like to learn more about Google Cloud services without these prerequisites. 

For more information, please see the CLE page at:

https://courses.ucsf.edu/course/view.php?id=8237

Digital Humanities Sequence

This sequence is designed for people with no prior programming experience. The workshops start with core python and sql before moving into more advanced or specialized topics in digital humanities, with an emphasis on text analysis and machine learning. 

You are welcome to take any of these workshops without attending the entire series. No formal pre-reqs are enforced, but if you are new to Python or SQL, you’ll get the core programming skills necessary for the later workshops by attending Intro to Python Part 1 and Part 2 along with Intro to SQL.

title: 3D Printing Part 1: Intro to 3D Printing
description:
Are you curious about the applications for 3D printing at UCSF?

Join Makers Lab staff for the first pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D printing and how the technology can be used in the health sciences.  

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. List the main components of a 3D printer
  2. Identify four methods for obtaining 3D models
  3. Recognize which is the ideal 3D printer for your project
  4. Generate a print time estimate for a given 3D model
  5. Execute a 3D print from start to finish

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: 3D Printing Materials Overview
description:
Are you interested in the multitude of materials you can 3D print with?

The materials used when 3D printing are often just as important as what you are 3D printing. With so many options available...where do you start?

Makers Lab staff will provide an overview of 3D printing materials used in the Makers Lab. Learn about the properties and applications of commonly used 3D printing materials. Discover the right material for your project and uncover the possibilities!

By the end of this pop-up you will be able to:

  1. List the different types of materials commonly used for 3D printing in the Makers Lab
  2. Recognize the key properties and applications of 3D printing materials
  3. Choose and request the most suitable material for your 3D printing project

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Super Searching: PubMed, Web of Science, Embase
description:
Let us show you how to get the best results from your search.

Go beyond Google search methods to get a handle on database logic. Build complex search strategies; try some PubMed tricks and tips, and set up alerts to stay informed when new articles are published in your field.

And try two other databases: Web of Science and Embase. In Web of Science you can identify articles, find where an author or article has been cited, and find articles an article has cited. In this database, articles are linked by citations. You can also find ‘hot articles’ and ‘highly cited articles.’ These are high-impact articles, receiving so many citations from other articles that they are in the top 1% of articles in their academic field.

Produced by Elsevier Science, Embase covers additional EU literature, so you will find unique citations here that are not in PubMed. It includes all of Medline plus over 2,000 extra titles, and 260,000 conference abstracts (over 24 million records from more than 7,500 journals). Embase covers the fields of medicine, biomedical sciences, drugs and pharmacy.

You will learn:

  • Structured database searching for more complex searches
  • PubMed tips and tricks
  • Basic Web of Science search features
  • Basic Embase search features

title: Ideation Drawing
description:
Are you interested in learning about visual communication and perspective drawing? Join Makers Lab staff (virtually) covering the process of illustrating basic shapes, 3-point perspective, and shading. 

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Define “ideation”
  2. Explain perspective drawing
  3. Draw basic shapes using perspective drawing fundamentals
  4. Demonstrate the ability to apply shading and incorporate light flow

Since this pop-up will be held on Zoom, we are unable to provide supplies. The materials you will need are a straight-edge, a writing utensil, and some paper. To facilitate the learning experience, you are encouraged to share your work during the session.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Bay Area Open Science Group - Open and Collaborative Methods for Studying Human Emotion
description:
This month the Bay Area Open Science Group will be joined by Nicholas Coles. Nicholas will discuss his experiences as a Research Scientist at the Stanford University Human-Centered AI center, where he conducts research on emotions, big team science, and quantitative methods. Nicholas is co-director of the Stanford Big Team Science Lab and won the Center for Open and Reproducible Science (CORES) Open Science Innovator Award. He also founded the Emotion Physiology and Experience Collaboration, which is working to develop the largest publicly available dataset on emotion physiology and experience. Before joining Stanford, he received his PhD in Social Psychology from the University of Tennessee, with additional postdoctoral training at Harvard University. Starting in August, Nicholas will be an Assistant Professor at the University of Florida Department of Psychology.

The Bay Area Open Science Group is intended to bring together students, faculty, and staff from the Stanford, UCSF, and Berkeley community to learn about open science, discuss the application of open science practices in a research context, and meet other members of the community who are interested in (or already are) incorporating open science practices into their work. Learn more about the group and connect with us on our website.

Register for this event via Zoom

title: Glyphosate Dreams: An Exhibition by UCSF Artist in Residence Katina Bitsicas
description:
Join us for the opening reception of Glyphosate Dreams, a multimedia art exhibition by the 2023 UCSF Artist in Residence, Katina Bitsicas. The reception will be held on the main floor of the UCSF Kalmanovitz Library on the Parnassus Heights campus and will include an overview of the exhibit and a conversation with the artist.

This exhibition visually translates the deadly herbicide glyphosate into chemically deteriorated images and an interactive AR experience reflecting on its consequences to body and land. Throughout Katina's residency at UCSF, she reviewed the Roundup Litigation Documents within the UCSF Industry Documents Library to select the most poignant parts of the email exchanges between the EPA and Monsanto to include in her photographic project using glyphosate to physically deteriorate C-prints over time as they were buried in the ground. Additionally, she used images from her personal archive of her family’s land that underwent the same image treatment and process. The results of these prints varied from partially deteriorated, highlighting specific sections of the print, to completely disintegrated, leaving behind a ghost-like image.

An augmented reality (AR) project then takes these deterioration patterns and animates them into a virtual work, enabling the viewer to place the deterioration on top of their inhabited land to visualize the detrimental effects instantaneously. A series of letterpress prints also feature the deterioration patterns from the glyphosate-treated archival images and segments of a lake depth chart map of Burt Lake, a frequented fishing spot, commenting on the effects of herbicides to our aquatic ecosystems. The deterioration patterns conceal and highlight various indication symbols on the map, guiding the viewer along their discovery of the map.

Contact the Makers Lab if you have questions about this event.

Image credit: Katina Bitsicas (2023). Glyphosate Dreams [Glyphosate treated C-print from personal archive, 30”x40”].

category.name: Archives and Special Collections > Artist in Residence

presenter: Katina Bitsicas, UCSF Library Artist in Residence

title: Needlecraft Monthly Meet-Up
description:
Calling all fans of knitting, crochet, cross-stitch, sewing, and embroidery!

This virtual meet-up is a chance for beginning and experienced UCSF crafters to come together and work on their projects in a fun and relaxed atmosphere. We hang, we chat, we work on fabulous projects, and share advice and inspiration. Join us!

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. See all upcoming Needlecraft Meet-Ups to save your seat today!

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Photo from meetup host and UCSF staff member Ariel

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.
